questions.text: Identify the false statement below

options.label: A
options.text: UC affects the colon, and it is a mucosal disease

options.label: B
options.text: Granulomas may be found on histology in UC

options.label: D
options.text: CD is often associated with perianal disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Granulomas may be found on histology in UC
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Granulomas may be found on histology in UC Option A C D: These are correct statements. Differences between ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn’s disease (CD): UC affects the colon ; CD can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract , particularly the small and large bowel. UC is a mucosal disease , whereas CD affects the total thickness of the bowel wall . UC produces confluent disease in the colon and rectum , whereas skip lesions characterize CD . CD more commonly causes structuring and fistulation . Granulomas may be found on histology in CD but not in UC. The CD is often associated with perianal disease , which is unusual in UC. CD affecting the terminal ileum may produce symptoms mimicking appendicitis , but this does not occur in UC. Resection of the colon and rectum cures the patient with UC , whereas recurrence is common after resection in CD .

Highyeild:

Crohn's disease Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory gastrointestinal tract disease, but the cause is unknown. It can affect any part of the digestive system, from the mouth to the anus, but it most commonly affects the small intestine and colon. In 55% of cases, the large and small intestines are involved. In 30% of cases, only the small intestine is involved, and in 15% of cases, only the large intestine is involved. Ulcerative colitis Ulcerative colitis is more common in developed countries. It more commonly affects patients under 30 and is more common in females taking oral contraceptive pills. It is more common in whites, Jews, and persons of northern European ancestry. The exact cause of ulcerative colitis is unknown, but infectious agents such as difficile and Campylobacter jejuni have been implicated as possible causes.

questions.text: Extraintestinal manifestation of Crohn’s disease unrelated to disease activity is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary sclerosing cholangitis Option B C D: Are extra-intestinal manifestations of Crohn’s Disease related to disease activity. Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn’s disease: Related to disease activity: Erythema nodosum Pyoderma gangrenosum Arthropathy Eye complications (iritis/uveitis) Aphthous ulceration Amyloidosis Unrelated to disease activity: Gallstones Renal calculi Primary sclerosing cholangitis Chronic active hepatitis Sacroiliitis

Highyeild:

The extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease (CD) are similar to those of ulcerative colitis (UC). Primary sclerosing cholangitis is less common in CD than in In CD, inflammation or absence of the terminal ileum can lead to gallstones due to reduced absorption of bile salts. Amyloidosis is a common occurrence in CD, but it is typically asymptomatic. CD can metastasize to the skin or vagina, causing nodular ulcers demonstrating non-caseating granulomas on Cutaneous CD can be similar to hidradenitis suppurativa macroscopically.

questions.text: CHRPE is associated with
questions.explanation:
Solution:

FAP Familial adenomatous polyposis: Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is defined clinically by the presence of more than 100 colorectal adenomas but is also characterized by duodenal adenomas and multiple extraintestinal manifestations. Over 80% of cases come from patients with a positive family history. The remainder arises due to new mutations in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene on the short arm of chromosome 5. FAP is inherited as an autosomal dominant condition and is equally likely in men and women. The lifetime risk of colorectal cancer is 100% in patients with FAP. Up to 50% of patients with FAP have congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) , which can be used to screen affected families if genetic testing is unavailable

Highyeild:

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) FAP is diagnosed by over 100 colorectal, duodenal adenomas, and other extraintestinal manifestations. FAP is caused mainly by positive family history, but new mutations in the APC gene can also cause it. FAP is an autosomal dominant condition that affects both men and women equally. Individuals with APC gene mutation have a lifetime risk of colorectal cancer of up to 100%. FAP can also be associated with benign mesodermal tumors such as desmoid and osteomas, and epidermoid cysts can also occur. Regular endoscopic surveillance is necessary; screening should begin at 12-14 years old.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B C D . CHRPE is associated with FAP, not HNPCC, Peutz jeers, or carcinoid tumors.

Extraedge:

Examination of blood relatives is essential, and referral to a medical geneticist is necessary. If over 100 adenomas are present at colonoscopy , the diagnosis of FAP can be made confidently. Surgery is usually deferred until 17-18 unless symptoms develop, and malignant change is uncommon before age 20.

questions.text: A drug used in Rescue therapy for severe colitis is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vedolizumab Medical Treatment-Ulcerative Colitis: Medical therapy is based on anti-inflammatory agents. The 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) derivatives can be given topically (per rectum) or systemically. They act as inhibitors of the cyclo-oxygenase enzyme system and are formulated to protect the aspirin-related drug from degradation before reaching the colon. They can be used long-term as maintenance therapy.

Highyeild:

The initial treatment for severe acute colitis is with intravenous steroids . Fluid and electrolyte balance should be maintained, anemia corrected, and adequate nutrition, often parenterally. In some cases, immunosuppressive therapy with intravenous cyclosporin A or an anti-TNFα agent (Vedolizumab) may be appropriate . Surgery should be considered if rescue therapy does not result in rapid clinical improvement. Urgent colectomy may be necessary in cases of clinical deterioration.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for ‘flare ups’, either topically or systemically, and have a widespread anti-inflammatory action. The immunosuppressive drugs azathioprine and cyclosporine can be used to maintain remission and as ‘steroid-sparing’ agents. Option: C . The monoclonal antibodies infliximab and adalimumab act against antitumor necrosis factor-alpha, central to inflammatory cascades. Most recently, vedolizumab , which blocks integrins, has been used as ‘rescue therapy’ for severe colitis to try and avoid emergency colectomy.

Extraedge:

Mild attacks of colitis can be treated with a course of oral prednisolone. Moderate colitis attacks may respond to oral prednisolone, steroid enemas, and 5-ASA. If outpatient treatment fails to achieve remission, admission to the hospital may be necessary. Acute severe colitis can occur in up to 10% of patients and requires hospital Regular assessment of vital signs, weight, and the abdomen is necessary for proper management. Keeping a stool chart and regular clinical reviews are essential for monitoring progress. Supine abdominal radiographs should be done when there is a concern for toxic megacolons.

questions.text: True about Irritable bowel syndrome is/are

options.label: A
options.text: By definition, the symptoms have to present for at least three days per week

options.label: B
options.text: Surgery is indicated if medical therapy fails

options.label: C
options.text: Hypnotherapy or cognitive behavioral therapy may be beneficial

questions.correct_answer: C. Hypnotherapy or cognitive behavioral therapy may be beneficial
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypnotherapy or cognitive behavioral therapy may be beneficial Irritable bowel syndrome: The term irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) covers a range of symptoms with a functional basis. Clinical features are variable but abdominal discomfort, bloating, irregular bowel habit, and passage of mucus are familiar.

Highyeild:

IBS is a functional bowel disorder characterized by abdominal discomfort, stool irregularities, and bloating. The term IBS was coined in 1979 to replace outdated terms such as " irritable " or " spastic " colon. Diagnostic criteria have been updated and are now defined by the Rome IV Foundation. To meet the criteria for IBS, a patient must experience recurrent abdominal pain for at least one day a week for the past three months, along with two or more of the following: the pain is related to defecation, there is a change in stool frequency, or there is a change in stool form. The patient must have experienced symptoms for at least six months before diagnosis. IBS is divided into three subclasses based on the type of stool irregularity: constipation-predominant (IBS-C), diarrhea-predominant (IBS-D), and mixed (IBS-M).

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. By definition, the symptoms of pain have to have been present for at least three days per month for at least the three previous months in the six months before diagnosis (Rome criteria). IBS is common, and symptoms have been said to occur in up to 20% of the population. Colonic investigations are typically performed to rule out organic disease (colonoscopy, barium enema, or CT virtual colonoscopy) but are, by definition, normal. Treatment of IBS is difficult . Many patients benefit from reassurance and symptomatic treatment; dietary modifications, including fiber for constipation, avoidance of fermentable carbohydrates, and reduction of caffeine and nicotine intake, may be of value. Antidiarrheals and antispasmodic agents are commonly prescribed, but the evidence of benefit is poor. There is some evidence of benefit for low-dose tricyclic antidepressants, but patients are often reluctant to use them. Psychological treatments, including hypnotherapy and cognitive behavioral therapy, may be beneficial. Option: B. Surgery is contraindicated. Option: D . All of the above cannot be the answer

questions.text: Treatment option for Sigmoid volvulus is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Treatment of sigmoid volvulus: Flexible sigmoidoscopy or rigid sigmoidoscopy and insertion of a flatus tube should be carried out to allow deflation of the gut. The tube should be secured with tape for 24 hours, and a repeat x-ray is taken to ensure that decompression has occurred. Success, as long as the ischaemic bowel is excluded, will resolve the acute problem. In young patients, an elective sigmoid colectomy is required. It is reasonable not to offer any further treatment following successful endoscopic decompression in the elderly as there is a high death rate (~80% at two years) from causes other than recurrent volvulus. In elderly patients with co-morbidities and recurrent episodes of volvulus, the options are resection or two-point fixation with combined endoscopic/percutaneous tube insertion (gastrostomy tubes are frequently used for this purpose). Failure results in an early laparotomy, with untwisting of the loop and per annum decompression. When the bowel is viable, fixation of the sigmoid colon to the posterior abdominal wall may be safer in inexperienced hands. Resection is preferable if it can be achieved safely. A Paul–Mikulicz procedure is useful, particularly if there is suspicion of impending gangrene; an alternative procedure is a sigmoid colectomy. When the anastomosis is considered unwise, a Hartmann’s procedure with subsequent anastomosis can be carried out.

Highyeild:

Sigmoid volvulus Volvulus can occur in any segment of large bowel attached to a long and floppy mesentery or fixed to the retroperitoneum by a narrow base of origin. The sigmoid colon is the most common site of volvulus. Volvulus can be both clockwise or anticlockwise but is more commonly anticlockwise. Age, chronic constipation, institutionalization, neurological impairment, and a high-fiber diet are associated predisposing factors . Sigmoid volvulus presents as acute or subacute intestinal obstruction with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and obstipation. Radiological characteristics include a markedly dilated sigmoid colon with the appearance of a bent inner tube or coffee bean appearance, and contrast enema demonstrates the point of obstruction with the pathognomic "birds beak" or "bird of prey" or "ace of spades" sign.

Extraedge:

Initial management includes resuscitation followed by endoscopic decompression and detorsion, which can be achieved by placing a rectal tube through a proctoscope or using a colonoscopy. If detorsion/decompression cannot be achieved, laparotomy with sigmoid colon resection is done. Even if detorsion of the sigmoid volvulus is successful, the risk of recurrence is high. Sigmoid colectomy is indicated after the patient has stabilized. Any evidence of bowel gangrene or perforation contraindicates non-operative decompression, and an immediate surgical exploration, such as the Paul - Mikulicz operation, is done.

questions.text: A 62 year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening fatigue for six months. He has also had shortness of breath and palpitations on exertion. He has noticed blood in his stools on three separate occasions in the past four months but no other changes in bowel habits. He does not report any weight loss. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and end-stage renal disease. He drinks two to four beers daily. He does not smoke. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), his pulse is 95/min, and his blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctiva. The abdomen is soft with no organomegaly. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's bleeding?

options.label: A
options.text: Malignant transformation in colonic mucosal cells

options.label: B
options.text: Dilated submucosal veins in the lower third of esophagus

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic mucosal and submucosal inflammation of colon

options.label: D
options.text: Arteriovenous malformation in the colonic wall

questions.correct_answer: D. Arteriovenous malformation in the colonic wall
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arteriovenous malformation in the colonic wall This patient most likely has chronic intestinal bleeding due to arteriovenous malformation ( angiodysplasia ) in the colonic wall. Angiodysplasia is associated with advanced age (> 60 years ) and ESRD , as seen in this patient. In individuals with ESRD, ∼ 30 % of cases of lower GI bleeding are due to angiodysplasia. Other conditions associated with angiodysplasia include von Willebrand disease and aortic stenosis. To confirm the diagnosis in this patient, angiography should be performed. Angiodysplasia - prominent mucosal vessels in a right-sided colonic biopsy.

Highyeild:

Angiodysplasia (vascular ectasia) Vascular ectasia is the most common vascular lesion found in the colon. It is also the most common cause of recurrent lower intestinal bleeding after age 60. Vascular ectasia arises from age-related degeneration of previously normal colonic blood vessels and is an acquired condition. These lesions are usually multiple, less than 5 mm in diameter, and almost always occur in the cecum or the proximal ascending colon . Vascular ectasia is rarely identified with gross inspection or routine pathologic examination. Diagnosis can be made with colonoscopy or angiography . Angiography may reveal slow emptying of veins and dilation of submucosal vessels. Vascular ectasia is not associated with synchronous angiomatous skin lesions, mucous membranes, or other viscera. According to the API, hemorrhoids and anal fissures are the most common cause of lower GI bleeding, but the bleeding is rarely massive.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option:. A . Colon cancer may present with hematochezia and anemia due to chronic lower GI bleeding, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other typical symptoms of colon cancer, such as weight loss, fever, night sweats, and changes in bowel habits. Moreover, although colon cancer should be investigated for and suspected in all elderly male patients with rectal bleeding, it is not the most common epidemiological cause of rectal bleeding in this demographic group. Therefore, the likelihood of cancer being the cause of this patient's rectal bleeding is not the highest. Option: B. Esophageal varices are the most common cause of esophageal bleeding. Heavy alcohol consumption, as seen in this patient, increases the risk for alcoholic liver disease and cirrhosis, which may eventually lead to the formation of esophageal varices and subsequent variceal bleeding. While variceal bleeding usually manifests with sudden onset of hematemesis and severe hemorrhage, this patient presents with a history of chronic blood loss, recurrent bloody stools, and gradual progression of symptoms over the past six months. Option: C . Tissue ischemia due to decreased splanchnic perfusion is characteristic of ischemic colitis. This patient's ESRD and diabetes mellitus increased his risk for ischemic colitis. While ischemic colitis can lead to GI bleeding, it typically presents with a sudden onset of symptoms as opposed to this patient's gradual progression of clinical findings over the past six months. Moreover, ischemic colitis would present with severe periumbilical pain, diarrhea, and high fever.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was diagnosed with Crohn's disease 7 years ago. He was told for an annual colonoscopic examination. Which of the following is not the use of routinely done colonoscopy in Ulcerative Colitis?

options.label: A
options.text: To assess the extent of the disease.

options.label: B
options.text: To distinguish it from Crohn’s disease.

options.label: C
options.text: To carry out surveillance for the development of cancer.

options.label: D
options.text: To assess severity in acute cases.

questions.correct_answer: D. To assess severity in acute cases.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To assess severity in acute cases. Colonoscopy has a vital role in the management of UC. Once suspected, a colonoscopy is carried out to determine the extent of the disease and confirm the diagnosis by taking biopsies at various levels. Macroscopically, continuous disease and the absence of ‘skip lesions’ will set it apart from Crohn’s disease . The procedure is also useful as a follow-up to monitor response to medical treatment. Patients with the disease for >10 years have an increased chance of developing cancer. So such patients should undergo annual colonoscopic surveillance and biopsies to exclude dysplasia or cancer. It should not be done in the acute stage for fear of causing a perforation.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, B & C. These are the uses of routinely done colonoscopies in UC.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the criteria for severe disease in Ulcerative Colitis?

options.label: A
options.text: More than six motions per day.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tachypnoea > 20/minute. It is important to recognize the severe disease in UC because treatment should be aggressive, otherwise the patient might go into fulminant disease or perforation.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A, B & C. Severe UC should be diagnosed if the patient has more than six bloody stools a day, pyrexia of >37.50 C, tachycardia of >90/minute, and albumin of <30g/L. Tachypnoea, although important, is not one of the criteria. Inflammatory markers such as ESR and CRP are elevated. Plain abdominal X-rays are done to look for toxic megacolon.

questions.text: A 23 year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of lower abdominal pain. She has also had multiple episodes of loose stools with blood during this period. She has had painful bowel movements for one month. Over the past year, she has had a 10-kg weight loss. She was treated for streptococcal pharyngitis last week. Her maternal grandfather died of colon cancer at the age of 52 years. She does not smoke. She drinks three to five beers on social occasions. She is 162 cm tall and weighs 52 kg; her BMI is 19.7 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C, her pulse is 60/min, her respirations are 13/min, and her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft, and there is tenderness to palpation of the left lower quadrant. There is no guarding or rigidity. Rectal examination shows no masses. Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are positive. Colonoscopy is scheduled for the next day. Which of the following findings is most likely present on this patient's colonoscopy?

options.label: A
options.text: Pseudo membranes overlying regions of colonic inflammation

options.label: B
options.text: Patchy inflammation of mucosa with cobblestone appearance and intervening areas of normal mucosa

options.label: C
options.text: Confluent inflammation of colonic mucosa with edema, fibrin-covered ulcers, and loss of vascular pattern.

questions.correct_answer: C. Confluent inflammation of colonic mucosa with edema, fibrin-covered ulcers, and loss of vascular pattern.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Confluent inflammation of colonic mucosa with edema, fibrin-covered ulcers, and loss of vascular pattern. Confluent inflammation of colonic mucosa with edema, fibrin-covered ulcers, and loss of vascular pattern. This option describes the findings of ulcerative colitis on endoscopy. Colonoscopy shows mucosal edema, reduced vascular markings, and broad-based linear or collar-button ulcers covered with fibrin. In advanced disease, isolated islands of regenerating mucosa within the ulcers protrude into the lumen of the intestine, giving rise to pseudopolyps. Lastly, chronic inflammation leads to mucosal atrophy, resulting in a loss of mucosal folds and vascular pattern.

Highyeild:

Table - 1 Distinguishing ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease (CD). UC CD Macroscopic Distribution Rectum Perianal disease Fistula formation Stricture Colon/rectum Always involved Rare Rare Rare Anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract Often spared Common Common Common Microscopic Layers involved Granulomas Fissuring Crypt abscesses Mucosa/submucosa No No Common Full thickness Common Common Rare

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. This option describes the findings of pseudomembranous colitis , most commonly caused by Clostridium difficile . However, the patient's history and a positive p-ANCA suggest that she has ulcerative colitis, which is not associated with pseudomembrane formation. Option: B. This option describes the findings of Crohn's disease on endoscopy. The lesions in Crohn's disease are multiple, sharply delineated areas of inflammation with intervening regions of normal mucosa. These delineated regions slowly coalesce to form long, serpiginous ulcers between normal mucosa, thus giving the mucosa a cobblestone appearance. Option: D. A patient with chronic abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss as well as normal findings on colonoscopy should receive a gastroduodenoscopy to check for small intestinal diseases like celiac disease. Biopsies should also be taken to exclude microscopic colitis. However, this patient's presentation is most likely due to ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A 31 -year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 5-week history of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea that has worsened in the past 24 hours. She was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis one year ago but has had difficulty complying with her drug regimen. Her temperature is 38.2°C, her pulse is 120/min, and her blood pressure is 92/56 mm Hg. Examination shows a distended, rigid abdomen and hypoactive bowel sounds. Fluid resuscitation is initiated. Which is the most appropriate next step in diagnosing this patient's current condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Abdominal x-ray Abdominal X-ray is the next appropriate step in diagnosing suspected bowel perforation. CT angiography is a confirmatory test used to diagnose acute mesenteric ischemia , which can present with an acute onset of bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain and distention, hypoactive bowel sounds, and, in case of bowel necrosis, signs of sepsis. However, AMI usually occurs in patients > 60 years with cardiovascular risk factors . This 32-year-old patient presents with a 5-week history of bloody diarrhea. She lacks risk factors for the development of AMI, such as atrial fibrillation , valvular heart disease, or a recent history of critical illness.

Highyeild:

Certain medical conditions increase the risk of non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia . Some of these conditions are acute myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, and dysrhythmia. Other factors that increase the risk of non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia include sepsis, hypovolemia, use of splanchnic vasoconstrictors, and being a hemodialysis patient . Patients who have had major abdominal surgery, pancreatitis, aortic dissection, or burns may also be at an increased risk of non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A.Double-contrast barium enema is an imaging modality used to diagnose UC because it can identify subtle mucosal changes (e.g., micro ulcerations, pseudopolyps) that may be missed on other imaging modalities. However, the diagnosis of UC has already been established in this patient. More importantly, barium enema is contraindicated in patients with suspected toxic megacolon because it would further increase colonic distension and thus risk colonic perforation. Option: B. A contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) is limited in diagnosing toxic megacolon . A CT scan can be considered if the first-line diagnostic modality is inconclusive or to identify better possible complications of toxic megacolon, such as perforation and bowel ischemia. Option: C. CT angiography is a confirmatory test used to diagnose acute mesenteric ischemi a, which can present with an acute onset of bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain and distention, hypoactive bowel sounds, and, in case of bowel necrosis, signs of sepsis. However, AMI usually occurs in patients > 60 years with cardiovascular risk factors. This 32-year-old patient presents with a 5-week history of bloody diarrhea. She lacks risk factors for the development of AMI, such as atrial fibrillation, valvular heart disease, or a recent history of critical illness.

Extraedge:

Angiography is the investigation of choice for acute mesenteric ischemia . Aortography is the preferred investigation for chronic mesenteric ischemia . CECT (contrast-enhanced computed tomography) is the preferred investigation for mesenteric venous thrombosis .

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of abdominal pain and bloody, mucoid diarrhea for three days. He has been taking over-the-counter supplements for constipation over the past six months. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His current medications include metformin. His temperature is 38.4°C, his pulse is 92/min, and his blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg. Examination of the abdomen shows no masses. Palpation of the left lower abdomen elicits tenderness. A barium enema of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition

options.label: A
options.text: Focal weakness of colonic muscularis layer

options.label: D
options.text: Twisting of sigmoid colon around its mesentery

questions.correct_answer: A. Focal weakness of colonic muscularis layer
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Focal weakness of colonic muscularis layer Saw tooth appearance is seen on the Barium enema . Focal weakness of the colonic muscular layer, typically at points where the vasa recta traverse the intestinal wall, allows for the formation of protrusions of mucosal and submucosal layers in response to increased intraluminal pressure (e.g., from chronic constipation). These protrusions (i.e., diverticula) are referred to as “ pseudodiverticula ” because not all layers of the intestinal wall are affected. Diverticulosis is the asymptomatic presence of these protrusions (identified as air-filled pouches on CT). Diverticulitis is an acute inflammation of the diverticula that typically manifests with bowel wall thickening on CT, fever, left-sided lower abdominal pain, and bloody mucoid diarrhea, all seen in this patient. Risk factors for the diverticular disease include diet (low in fiber, high in red meat and fat), BMI ≥ 25 kg/m2, lack of physical activity, and smoking (≥ 40 pack-years).

Highyeild:

Diverticula can be true or false . A true diverticulum comprises all layers of the intestinal wall, while a false diverticulum lacks a portion of the standard bowel wall. Acquired diverticula are the most common type and are mainly false diverticula . Diverticula occur due to herniation of mucosa through the muscular propria, often at the point where the nutrient artery penetrates through the colonic wall.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. An infiltrative growth in the descending colon is consistent with left-sided colorectal cancer (CRC) . CRC can manifest with changes in bowel habits (e.g., diarrhea), rectal bleeding, and abdominal pain. However, as opposed to this patient's acute presentation, symptoms usually develop over a long period. Moreover, nonspecific symptoms (e.g., weight loss, night sweats, fatigue) would be expected at that point. Also, a CT scan typically shows a soft tissue density mass causing narrowing of the bowel lumen; adjacent air-filled pouches are not found in this condition. Option: C. Transmural inflammation of the terminal ileum is consistent with Crohn's disease (CD) . CD may manifest with low-grade fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, as seen in this patient. However, he lacks other typical features of CD, such as signs of malabsorption (e.g., weight loss, anemia) and extraintestinal symptoms (e.g., arthritis, erythema nodosum). A CT scan of a patient with CD may show bowel wall thickening, fat stranding, and strictures or fistulas; air-filled pouches are not typically seen in this condition. Option: D. Twisting the sigmoid colon around its mesentery is consistent with sigmoid volvulus , which can lead to bowel obstruction, infarction, and perforation. Sigmoid volvulus typically manifests with episodic abdominal pain, asymmetric abdominal distention, and progressive signs of bowel obstruction. Rectal bleeding, hematemesis, and peritonitis may also be present in severe cases. CT scan typically shows gas-filled loops of the bowel, twisting of the mesentery and mesenteric vessels ( whirl sign ), and gradual narrowing or tapering of the sigmoid colon up to the level of obstruction ( bird beak sign ), none of which are seen here.

Extraedge:

Diverticulosis is more common in the Western world and rare in underdeveloped and developing countries where diets include more fiber and roughage.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 7-week history of blood in his stool. Two months ago, he had an episode of bronchitis and was treated with amoxicillin. Since then, he has occasionally noticed blood in his stool and toilet paper. The patient has had intermittent constipation for the past five years. Six months ago, he had severe left lower quadrant pain and fever, resolved with antibiotic therapy. He underwent a colonoscopy three years ago, showing no malignancy evidence. He takes levothyroxine for hypothyroidism. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years but quit ten years ago. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 136/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and non-tender with no organomegaly. Digital rectal examination shows no masses. The test of the stool for occult blood is positive. His Hb is 10g/dl. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diverticulosis Diverticulosis is a condition in which bulging-out pouches develop in the colon's wall, mostly the sigmoid colon, and is often associated with chronic constipation. This patient has all the classic symptoms of diverticulosis : constipation, abdominal pain, and anemia (due to bleeding) . He also has several risk factors, including smoking, alcohol consumption, advanced age, and obesity . Constipation may also be associated with his history of hypothyroidism. Occasionally, diverticular pouches can become inflamed and cause diverticulitis, which could explain this patient's previous LLQ pain and fever.

Highyeild:

Diverticula can be true or false . A true diverticulum comprises all layers of the intestinal wall, while a false diverticulum lacks a portion of the normal bowel wall. Acquired diverticula are the most common type and are mainly false diverticula . Diverticula occur due to herniation of mucosa through the muscularis propria, often at the point where the nutrient artery penetrates through the colonic wall.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Colorectal carcinoma can present with many symptoms, such as hematochezia, anemia, fatigue, constipation, abdominal pain, and weight loss. While this patient has many of the same symptoms, he does not show weight loss or fatigue. Colorectal carcinoma would also not explain the previous LLQ pain and fever episode. Furthermore, this patient's normal colonoscopy three years ago makes colorectal cancer less likely. Option: C. Ischemic colitis occurs when the blood supply to the bowel is inadequate, causing inflammation and injury to the bowel. Ischemic colitis presents with abdominal pain, hematochezia, diarrhea, and high fever. While this patient has abdominal pain and hematochezia, his chronic constipation and normal temperature suggest a different diagnosis. Option: D. An anal fissure is a tear of the anal canal distal to the dentate line and can cause rectal bleeding, anorectal pain, and pruritus. Although constipation does predispose to developing tears in the anal tissues and resulting fissures, this patient's rectal exam and lack of anorectal pain rule out an anal fissure.

Extraedge:

Diverticulosis is more common in the Western world and rare in underdeveloped and developing countries where diets include more fiber and roughage.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient has had complaints of blood in stools for 4 weeks. He was diagnosed with Diverticulosis. Which of the following most likely prevented this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High fiber diet A low-fiber diet is associated with chronic constipation. By contrast, a high-fiber diet can help alleviate symptoms of constipation and prevent development of diverticulosis by reducing intraluminal pressure and minimizing straining.

Highyeild:

Diverticula can be true or false . A true diverticulum is composed of all layers of the intestinal wall, while a false diverticulum lacks a portion of the normal bowel wall. Acquired diverticula are the most common type and are mainly false diverticula . Diverticula occur due to herniation of mucosa through the muscularis propria, often at the point where the nutrient artery penetrates through the colonic wall.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Long-term use of low-dose aspirin has a protective effect on the development of colon cancer. However, it has no protective effect on the development of diverticulosis. In fact, use of aspirin has been correlated with an increased risk of diverticulitis and diverticular bleeding. Option: C. Anticoagulation with warfarin may help to treat or prevent ischemic colitis if it is secondary to cardiac thromboembolism from atrial fibrillation or mesenteric venous thrombosis. Warfarin use would have no benefit in patients with diverticulosis but is a risk factor for diverticular bleeding. Option: D. Antibiotic use is associated with alterations in the microbiome of the bowel. Removal of normal colonizing intestinal flora may allow for colonization by difficile and subsequent development of pseudomembranous colitis . However, the patient's bleeding is from diverticulosis, and antibiotics do not increase the risk of this condition.

Extraedge:

Diverticulosis is more common in the western world and rare in underdeveloped and developing countries where diets include more fiber and roughage.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman complains of blood-stained diarrhea with passage of slime on and off for 6 months. She passes 4 to 6 loose motions a day; this is associated with tenesmus and generalized vague abdominal pain and a feeling of ill health. She has lost some weight and recently found a raised, tender red swelling on her shin. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ulcerative colitis Patients with ulcerative colitis might present electively or as an emergency. The usual sufferer complains of loose stools with blood and mucus. Sometimes she has to rush to the toilet and might be caught short. They suffer with a feeling of insufficient evacuation and tenesmus. Colicky left-sided abdominal pain usually accompanies the loose stools. examination there is not much to find except for some left iliac fossa tenderness and blood and mucus on rectal examination. They also have extraintestinal manifestations which is also seen in this case.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Angiodysplasia - The typical presentation is with lower gastrointestinal bleeding that can be overt or occult. When the bleeding is overt it might be profuse, resulting in hypovolemic shock. Option: B. Patients with caecal carcinoma can present as an emergency or electively, the latter presentation being due to the primary tumor or metastatic disease such as liver secondaries. The presentation is from features of iron deficiency anemia due to chronic occult bleeding or pain and lump over the right side of the abdomen. Sometimes, patients present with symptoms due to metastatic disease. This can be in the form of jaundice due to liver secondaries. Option: C. Patients with colovesical fistula present primarily with urinary symptoms such as dysuria, recurrent urinary tract infections, attacks of ascending pyelonephritis, pneumaturia and passing foul-smelling urine due to feces in the urine.

questions.text: A 53 year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 24-hour history of severe lower abdominal pain. She has had two episodes of nonbloody vomiting today and has been unable to keep down food or fluids. She has not had a bowel movement since the day before. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 20 years. Her temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a soft abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds. There is moderate left lower quadrant tenderness. A tender mass is palpable on digital rectal examination. There is no guarding or rebound tenderness.Her Leukocyte count is 17,000/mm3. Which of the following is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

questions.correct_answer: D. CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT scan of the abdomen with contrast The patient has findings consistent with acute diverticulitis . Abdominal CT with oral and intravenous contrast is the test of choice for diagnosing diverticulitis. Typical CT findings include bowel wall thickening (> 4 mm) and inflammation of the pericolonic fat with fat stranding (visible traces of fluid in the fat) . A CT scan is also helpful in ruling out complications such as abscess (fluid collections surrounded by inflammatory changes), obstruction (dilated intestinal loops, air-fluid levels), perforation (free air in the abdominal cavity), and fistula (air in organs other than the bowel).

Highyeild:

Diverticula can be true or false . A true diverticulum is composed of all layers of the intestinal wall, while a false diverticulum lacks a portion of the normal bowel wall. Acquired diverticula are the most common type and are mainly false diverticula . Diverticula occur due to herniation of mucosa through the muscularis propria, often at the point where the nutrient artery penetrates through the colonic wall.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Colonoscopy is contraindicated in this patient with an acute episode of diverticulitis, because the inflammation may be exacerbated by the procedure and the risk of perforation is increased. Colonoscopy is typically performed once the inflammation has subsided (typically after 6 weeks) to assess the extent of diverticulitis and rule out malignancy. Rectal cancer is an important differential diagnosis in a patient with a palpable mass on digital rectal examination. However, given the acute presentation with systemic signs of inflammation (fever, leukocytosis) and the tenderness of the mass, diverticulitis is more likely. Option: B. Abdominal ultrasonography can be performed if other imaging techniques are unavailable. Abdominal ultrasound would typically show diverticula, hypoechoic peridiverticular inflammation, abscess formations (detectable fluid), or bowel wall thickening . However, ultrasound is not the test of choice for the diagnosis of diverticulitis. Option: C. Exploratory laparotomy may be considered in patients with severe abdominal pain that cannot be evaluated sufficiently by noninvasive diagnostic methods. This patient's clinical presentation strongly suggests diverticulitis, which can be confirmed or ruled out with a diagnostic test, rendering exploratory laparotomy unnecessary.

Extraedge:

Diverticulosis is more common in the Western world and rare in underdeveloped and developing countries where diets include more fiber and roughage.

questions.text: Three days after undergoing an open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair, a 66 -year-old woman has crampy abdominal pain. She has also had two episodes of loose, bloody stools during this period. Her surgery was complicated by severe blood loss requiring the administration of vasopressors and multiple transfusions. Cefazolin was administered as a perioperative antibiotic. The patient has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and coronary artery disease. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 50 years and drinks 3–4 glasses of wine weekly. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.0°C, her pulse is 110/min, and her blood pressure is 96/58 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a distended abdomen with absent bowel sounds. The core is exquisitely tender to palpation in all quadrants. The lungs are clear to auscultation. An x-ray of the abdomen shows an air-filled distended bowel. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ischemic colitis In ischemic colitis , sudden blood flow compromise results in bowel wall injury, which may progress to necrosis and infection. During abdominal aortic repairs, instrumentation of the aorta can produce emboli that lodge in downstream vessels and cause ischemia, which may be worsened by significant blood loss and vasopressor use. Clinically, ischemic colitis typically presents in three phases : hyperactive phase of crampy abdominal pain with bloody, loose stools ; paralytic phase with diffuse pain, bloating, absent bowel sounds, and cessation of stools ; shock phase with signs of peritonitis and septic shock . These phases can be clearly identified in this patient's clinical course, as her vital signs indicate early signs of developing shock.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A.Abdominal compartment syndrome can result from the accumulation of blood (e.g., following surgery) or fluid in the intra-abdominal space causing elevated intra-abdominal pressure. The condition leads to abdominal distention and multiorgan-system dysfunction secondary to reduced cardiac output due to decreased venous return. Although this patient has hypotension, tachycardia, and abdominal distention, bloody stools are not typically associated with abdominal compartment syndrome. Additionally, oliguria, renal failure, tachypnea, wheezing, and nausea/vomiting would likely be present, making this diagnosis unlikely. Option: B. Postoperative ileus is considered physiologic for hours to days immediately following abdominal surgery. This period may be longer following open surgery and surgery complicated by bleeding, infection, and inflammation. It is considered pathological if it persists for > 3–5 days and is accompanied by nausea/vomiting, absence of flatus, abdominal distention, diffuse abdominal pain, and reduction of bowel sounds. A plain abdominal X-ray may show dilated bowel loops with air in the colon and rectum. Despite this patient's complicated postoperative course, the fact that she has had bowel movements suggests that her postoperative ileus has resolved. Option: C. Recent systemic antibiotic use and hospital exposure can put patients at risk for C. difficile infection with the development of pseudomembranous colitis . The most common triggers include clindamycin, fluoroquinolones, and cephalosporins, including cefazolin, which was given to the patient preoperatively. Following C. difficile infection, patients develop cramping abdominal pain, fever, and multiple episodes per day of diarrhea, which can progress to fulminant colitis with abdominal distention and hypovolemia. However, diarrhea from pseudomembranous colitis is characteristically foul-smelling, watery, and frequent in contrast to this patient's 2 episodes of bloody stools.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 5 hours after the sudden onset of diffuse abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and two episodes of bloody stools. She has hypertension treated with nifedipine; she has not had any previous surgeries. She appears uncomfortable, tired, and diaphoretic. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), her pulse is 105/min and irregular, her respirations are 24/min, and her blood pressure is 106/66 mm Hg. Carotid, brachial, and femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness to palpation and diminished bowel sounds. The remainder of the study shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 18,300/mm3, and platelet count is 340,000/mm3. Exploratory laparotomy shows hyperemic and distended small bowel loops with multiple hemorrhagic and cyanotic patches. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Inflammatory disease of the bowel wall

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Occlusion of mesenteric artery The findings in this patient confirms bowel infarction. An occlusion of a mesenteric artery causes acute mesenteric ischemia and subsequent bowel infarction. This patient's irregular pulse indicates atrial fibrillation , which predisposes individuals to developing atrial thrombi. Embolization of a left atrial thrombus is the most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia . Thrombotic occlusion of a mesenteric vein (e.g., in patients with portal hypertension or hereditary thrombophilias) or mesenteric artery (e.g., in patients with atherosclerosis), and decreased blood flow to the mesenteric artery (e.g., in severe hypovolemia) are less common causes of acute mesenteric ischemia.

Highyeild:

Certain medical conditions increase the risk of non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia . Some of these conditions are acute myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, and dysrhythmia. Other factors that increase the risk of non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia include sepsis, hypovolemia, use of splanchnic vasoconstrictors, and being a hemodialysis patient .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Ulcerative colitis (UC) , one of the two forms of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), can result in acute hematochezia (due to acute fulminant colitis), bowel distention (due to a toxic megacolon), and bowel perforation with peritonitis and septic shock. However, the large intestine rather than the small intestine is affected in UC, and findings of bowel infarction would not be expected on laparotomy. Crohn’s disease , the other form of IBD, can affect the small bowel and cause chronic mechanical bowel obstruction with intestinal distention due to criticisms but does not typically cause an acute abdomen. Moreover, in both forms of IBD, patients usually have a history of chronic gastrointestinal symptoms, which this patient has not reported. Option: B. Perforation of an inflamed diverticular pouch ( diverticulitis ) can cause peritonitis and septic shock, both of which are seen here. Diverticulitis can also cause acute hematochezia. However, features of bowel infarction, which are seen during this patient's open laparotomy, are not expected; a laparotomy would instead show outpouching of the intestine wall, typically in the sigmoid colon (most common location) intestinal diverticula). Moreover, patients with diverticulitis typically report localized abdominal pain (usually in the left lower quadrant) before the onset of diffuse abdominal pain from peritonitis. Option: D. Invagination of a bowel segment ( intussusception ) can cause bowel infarction, which is seen here. However, bowel infarction would be restricted to the telescoping segment; it would not affect multiple bowel loops, as evidenced by this patient's laparotomy. Moreover, intussusception typically occurs in children, not elderly patients.

Extraedge:

Angiography is the investigation of choice for acute mesenteric ischemia . Aortography is the preferred investigation for chronic mesenteric ischemia . CECT (contrast-enhanced computed tomography) is the preferred investigation for mesenteric venous thrombosis .

questions.text: A 61 year-old man was brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of severe abdominal pain that started suddenly 1 hour ago while he was having dinner with his family. The pain is located in the middle of his abdomen, He feels nauseated and has vomited twice. He has also had episodes of loose stools. He was diagnosed with hypertension 2 years ago and was started on hydrochlorothiazide. He stopped taking his pills 1 week ago because of several episodes of heart racing and dizziness that he attributes to his medication. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. He is in severe distress. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows an irregular rhythm.Bowel sounds are normal. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. CT angiography is performed, and the diagnosis is confirmed. Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Balloon angioplasty and stenting The patient's findings are consistent with occlusion of mesenteric arteries. Performing balloon angioplasty and stenting is the preferred treatment for hemodynamically stable patients with acute mesenteric ischemia who do not manifest with signs or symptoms of advanced intestinal ischemia (e.g., peritonitis, sepsis). This procedure is minimally invasive, and studies suggest similar efficacy to open surgical treatment. Reassuring vital signs and benign abdominal examination findings in this patient suggest acute bowel ischemia without permanent infarction, which is likely to resolve with the restoration of blood flow.

Highyeild:

Certain medical conditions increase the risk of non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia . Some of these conditions are acute myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, and dysrhythmia. Other factors that increase the risk of non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia include sepsis, hypovolemia, use of splanchnic vasoconstrictors, and being a hemodialysis patient .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Explorative laparotomy is reserved for acutely ill patients at risk for rapid deterioration, including patients with acute mesenteric ischemia who are hemodynamically unstable or have evidence of peritonitis (rebound tenderness and involuntary guarding). Because this patient has stable vital signs and a benign abdominal exam, explorative laparotomy is not the preferred treatment. Option: B. Heparin anticoagulation is the definitive management of venous thromboembolism. Venous thrombosis accounts for < 10% of cases of acute mesenteric ischemia and is associated with milder symptoms that develop gradually (over weeks). Heparin anticoagulation primarily prevents clots from forming or expanding rather than breaking them apart, making it an insufficient treatment for arterial thromboembolism. This patient will likely receive heparin anticoagulation to limit the expansion of the thrombus before undergoing more definitive treatment. Option: C. Although colonoscopy is used to diagnose large bowel pathologies (e.g., lower gastrointestinal bleeding, inflammatory bowel disease, diverticulosis, colon cancer), it is not indicated for patients with acute mesenteric ischemia. Poor patient preparation will likely lead to poor colon visualization, and the diseased bowel is more prone to perforation when insufflating while advancing the scope.

Extraedge:

Angiography is the investigation of choice for acute mesenteric ischemia . Aortography is the preferred investigation for chronic mesenteric ischemia . CECT (contrast-enhanced computed tomography) is the preferred investigation for mesenteric venous thrombosis .

questions.text: A 69 year-old man comes to the physician accompanied by his wife because of a 5 month history of worsening episodic upper abdominal pain and an 8-kg weight loss. The pain is dull, nonradiating, worse after eating, and occasionally associated with bloating and diarrhea. His symptoms have not improved despite 4 weeks of treatment with omeprazole. He attributes his weight loss to recently eating very small portions and avoiding fatty foods. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He underwent a coronary artery bypass graft operation for coronary artery disease 8 years ago. His pulse is 79/min, and his blood pressure is 138/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft abdomen without tenderness to palpation or guarding. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. CT angiography of the abdomen
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT angiography of the abdomen Abdominal CT angiography is a confirmatory test for chronic mesenteric ischemia (CMI) , as it allows any occlusion in the splanchnic circulation to be visualized. In CMI, segments of the splanchnic circulation are stenosed due to atherosclerosis. These segments inhibit the normal postprandial increase in splanchnic circulation that is required for digestion, resulting in postprandial pain (intestinal angina), as seen here. Patients with CMI often develop an aversion to certain foods that trigger pain (food fear) and lose weight. This patient has many risk factors for CMI, including hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, chronic smoking, and coronary artery disease. As this patient has a high index of suspicion for CMI, a CT angiography is most likely to confirm the diagnosis.

Highyeild:

Treatment of chronic mesenteric ischemia (CMI) : Revascularization by balloon angioplasty or stent placement for elderly patients (poor candidates for surgery). Restenosis and reintervention rates may be high. Definitive therapy: Surgery with transaortic endarterectomy or bypass grafting. Results of surgery are generally highly gratifying in properly selected patients, with rapid resolution of symptoms and return of weight. Long-term patency of the grafts is excellent, exceeding.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Serum CA 19-9 is a tumor marker used to monitor the progression of pancreatic cancer and its response to therapy; it is not a confirmatory test. A tumor in the body or tail of the pancreas can manifest with upper abdominal pain and weight loss as the sole complaints (unlike a tumor in the pancreatic head, which manifests with obstructive jaundice). However, in pancreatic cancer , the pain is typically continuous, radiates to the back, and worsens at night and when lying down. This patient's intermittent, postprandial, non-radiating epigastric pain suggests a diagnosis that does not cause an elevation in CA 19-9. Option: B. Colonoscopy is the preferred diagnostic test when a colonic disease (e.g., colon cancer, diverticulosis, IBD) is suspected. Colonic pathologies typically cause colicky abdominal pain unrelated to food intake and associated with a significant alteration in bowel habits. This patient's upper abdominal pain worsens after meals, and occasional diarrhea is more consistent with an upper gastrointestinal pathology. Option: C. Right upper quadrant abdominal ultrasound is the preferred diagnostic test for gallbladder (GB) disease . Symptomatic cholelithiasis can manifest with intermittent postprandial upper abdominal pain (biliary colic) that is not relieved with acid suppression therapy, as seen in this patient. However, as biliary colic does not typically occur after each meal, patients do not develop food aversion or lose weight. GB malignancy can manifest with significant weight loss and can be detected on a RUQ ultrasound, but it typically does not cause postprandial abdominal pain. This patient's symptoms suggest a diagnosis that cannot be confirmed with RUQ ultrasound.

Extraedge:

Angiography is the investigation of choice for acute mesenteric ischemia . Aortography is the preferred investigation for chronic mesenteric ischemia . CECT (contrast-enhanced computed tomography) is the preferred investigation for mesenteric venous thrombosis .

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding mesenteric Ischemia?

options.label: A
options.text: There are three major mechanisms of visceral ischemia involving the mesenteric arteries: (a) acute mesenteric ischemia, which can be either embolic or thrombotic in origin; (b) chronic mesenteric ischemia; and (c) nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia.

options.label: B
options.text: Pain in chronic mesenteric Ischemia occurs immediately after eating.

options.label: C
options.text: The typical patient who develops nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia is an elderly patient with multiple comorbidities.

options.label: D
options.text: In acute embolic mesenteric ischemia, the emboli typically originate from a cardiac source

questions.correct_answer: B. Pain in chronic mesenteric Ischemia occurs immediately after eating.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pain in chronic mesenteric Ischemia occurs immediately after eating. The patient classically presents with severe central abdominal pain symptoms within 30- 60 minutes of eating. The typical patient who develops nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia is an elderly patient with multiple comorbidities, such as congestive heart failure, acute myocardial infarction with cardiogenic shock, and hypovolemic or hemorrhagic shock.

Highyeild:

Certain medical conditions increase the risk of non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia . Some of these conditions include acute myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, and dysrhythmia. Other factors that increase the risk of non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia include sepsis, hypovolemia, use of splanchnic vasoconstrictors, and being a hemodialysis patient . Patients who have had major abdominal surgery, pancreatitis, aortic dissection, or burns may also be at an increased risk of non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia

Random:

Explanation For Other Options:- Option: A, C & D. All other statements are true.

Extraedge:

Angiography is the investigation of choice for acute mesenteric ischemia . Aortography is the preferred investigation for chronic mesenteric ischemia . CECT (contrast-enhanced computed tomography) is the preferred investigation for mesenteric venous thrombosis .
